Key Arguments: The Bill violates democratic and constitutional rights to freedom of speech.
The statutory definition of 'misinformation' is over-broad and unworkable.
ACMA is not qualified to judge what constitutes 'misinformation'.
The Bill creates an unlevel playing field between governments and other speakers.
Governments and political parties are exempted from the Bill.
The Bill blames the informer for the behavior of the recipient.
It can be used to censor any information the government does not approve of.
The development of a code of practice is left to the industry, excluding the public.
No government or agency has a monopoly on truth.
The Bill will silence dissenting experts and lead to a totalitarian society.
Notable Quotes: Passing this Bill violates Australianâ€™s democratic and constitutional rights to freedom of speech which is the lifeblood of our democracy.
No one government or agency has a monopoly on truth.
It will lead to us becoming a totalitarian society.
